description: I originally checked this place out because I was intrigued by their "77 Chinese & Hawaiian BBQ" name, but when I got there, I noticed that their name had been changed to "77 Chinese & Vietnamese Cuisine."  You can order off their extensive Chinese/Vietnamese menu, or order a one, two or three item plate from their steam table (4 rice or noodle dishes, 14 entrees).  I've gone there twice now, and have only ordered from their steam table.  Food is fairly inexpensive ($9.75, tax included, for one item), appears very fresh (at noon), and service is extremely fast and friendly.  At 1.5 blocks from my office, the food is not as "whitewashed" as you might think, and a decent alternative to Chinatown.  I'd give it 3.5 Stars, but I guess 3.5 rounds up to 4.0.
author: Kyle T.

description:
A solid place for Chinese food and Vietnamese pho. Reasonable prices for downtown SF.

I enjoyed the spicy seafood pho, and also tried the 1 item combo.

Will come back to try other dishes.
author: Nicole S.

description:
This is my go-to place for five spiced chicken. Here are my recommendations:
1. Chicken salad: yes it can make you full. Once it's served to your partner who ordered it you'll start to regret why you haven't ordered it. It's the best stir fried (not deep fried) chicken you can get, and it has noodle in it so yep it can fill you up.
2. Special pho: well you don't go wrong with pho. This is one of the dishes that's hard to screw up, just like Korean BBQ beef...
3. Vege noodle soup. It has tomato soup as the base which makes you think it's spicy at the first place, but then you'd find it's a much more friendly taste.
A little downside here: you'd feel pretty full in the afternoon and that sometimes makes you feel sleepy...
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Starting off this review with my complaint of 15 cents for a take out bag. 
 WTF?????  15 cents????  Portions have gotten much smaller while food quality has gone downhill.  There used to be shrimp in their won tons, now it's some sort of pinkish mystery meat.  Wonton skins all broken up and the soup tastes like salt water.  I just gave this place my last chance.
author: Dynamic D.

description:
So I went in for the Chinese food and this place is pretty solid.  The hot tray items have been pretty good (I go for the shrimp veg dish & 5 spice chicken) and I got jook the other day (flavorful, definitely used chicken broth or stock since it had more chicken flavor than just dumping in some sliced chicken).

For Hawaiian, I'm gonna stick w/ my original assessment and say that L&L is a better bet, but I'll be back here for the Chinese and I'm eventually gonna try the pho sometime.
author: J S.

description: I've been here numerous times and agree it's a reasonably good place to eat in the downtown area and for the most part pretty tasty, so where did they go wrong?  I decided to try their soup with bok choy and the inner leaves were filled with dirt, the hot soup broth wasn't clear instead dirt was floating to the top. In addition, the attendees at the food buffet stand don't understand the concept of wearing gloves. They don't change their gloves after handling cash and credit cards so they refill the trays, prepare takeout food and handle money. After seeing all of this I decided to opt out on being one of my favorite go-to places...very sad indeed. It's very unsanitary.
author: Shirley P.

description: They have bun rieu here!!! And it's legit, authentic, crabby soup  I thought it was hopeless to find good Vietnamese food in FiDi, but this restaurant has proven me wrong!
author: Sarah H.

description:
Came here after suffering from my usual bout of indecision regarding a lunch option. Felt like something fast, filling, cheap, and maybe a tad unhealthy, so I figured Chinese food would fit that bill perfectly. And being that it was about 5 blocks away from the office, gave me a nice little jog to enjoy the fresh air before going back to work. Browsing through Yelp, I saw that 77 Chinese & Hawaii BBQ was nearby, and allowed online orders (saving me a wait in line when I arrived). 

When I first arrived here, I had a bit of trouble finding this little shop as I literally walked right by it without noticing it was even there. Had to pull up my Yelp app, and use the map to realize I walked a bit too far down Battery. Upon entering, instead of getting into their assembly style line, I saw that they had a "Order here" sign on the registers. Figuring that since I placed an online order (and paid for online), and that there was a sign at the counter, that I could logically skip the wait and go straight to the counters. While I still don't know if I followed the appropriate procedure, what I do know was that my wait at the counters was followed by about 5mins of awkwardness as the cashier proceeded to ignore me and avoid eye contact as she continued to ring up people coming from the other side of the line. Eventually, she turned around to one of her coworkers behind her, gestured at me and made some comment that I couldn't understand, and walked away. It was then and only then that anyone even bothered to come up and ask how they could help me. 

Service aside, I was also really disappointed by the food. Perhaps I should have ordered something different, but the Beef Chow Mein I ordered tasted rather rubbery, lacked any real flavor depth, and was extremely greasy. 

With all of the food options in FiDi, I think (aka I know) I will be skipping this place from now on.
author: Alex C.

description:
Strongly recommend their beef noodles. Try the wide pho instead of egg noodles. The soup tastes amazing for the price !! 
It's the most authentic Cantonese or Chinese or Vietnamese noodles soup in town. The staff is very friendly. It accepts card too!!
author: Eva F.

description:
Don't expect too much when you come here, this isn't a fancy chinese restaurant. If you're looking for a quick and cheap bite to eat during work, this place is perfect. There always seems to be no place to sit and there's always a small line, but you would never need to wait long. There's not many chinese restaurant around that's at this price range, and their food is actually pretty decent compared to other takeout places. I definitely recommend coming here if you're craving chinese food for lunch but don't have much time.

Chicken chowmein with Beef and Broccoli and Spicy Tofu takeout - $10
author: Henry H.

description:
QUICK LUNCH AT FINANCIAL DISTRICT

Working in the Financial District in SF I only have an hour for lunch. So during that time I have to make the most of lunch. This place is fairly close to my work. Most of the time when I come here it is for the soup whether it is wor wonton or chicken, egg, and soup. I like the soup here because the broth in the soup is clean. What I like about this place is there are selections that stand out from other Chinese eateries in SF. If I decide to order three items from the steam table one of those items has to be honey pepper pork. Sometimes from the "Specials of the Day" listed on the whiteboard I get items such as basil chicken fried rice or ginger salmon fried rice. Overall if I'm craving for Chinese food and want a quick lunch this place satisfies those needs.
author: Gerald R.

description:
House fried rice?  It was like whatever was left on the table. Hoping for decent fried rice while in San Fran, and it's the worst I've had in years.
The egg rolls were burnt and greasy as well
author: Bvibum E.

description: I give this restaurant 5 stars because it's conveniently located close to my work.  I don't have to walk blocks to Chinatown to get excellent Chinese food. The buffet selection is always fresh and delicious and you can also order from a menu. The wor wonton is the bomb! It's a small place with few tables and it's always crowded but it's worth waiting in line.
author: Cathy D.

description: This place has amazing portion sizes for chinese fast food, their pho comes with FiDi tax but is pretty decent, and they have the best banh mi downtown. Definitely try the sandwiches- again you pay FiDi tax but portion and quality wise nothing downtown beats it.
author: Bryan F.

description: This is my favorite place for wonton soup and to get away from the boring soup, salad, sandwiches and poke bowls that everyone seems to love around here. Disgusting! But here I love the salt and pepper fried ribs and wonton soup on a cold SF day
author: A g.

description: NO NO NO ... do not eat here! my head has been throbbing all day !  MSG is banned in most countries.. clearly not here!! I ate the 2 item combo with Shrimp and Tofu and it's the biggest mistake I made! Ruined my day ! Blah !
author: Megan V.

description:
I came here for lunch the other day and was pleasantly surprised.  The restaurant is small but there are two counters with bar stools at them so a bunch of lunch breakers can sit and eat-in, there are also a few small and larger dining tables.  You can either order food at the cash register that is made to order, or you can stand at the end of the steam table row and order a 1, 2 or 3 item plate (the same way you would at Panda).  Note that even though there is a sign that says  "Order here" at the cashier, you do not order there for the "buffet" style food. 

Your plate is served for you and you can choose steamed rice, fried rice or chow mein.  I got the chicken fried rice and it was great, it's the kind that (seems to me to be) more authentic and lighter in flavor, the rice appears white and there are few items mixed in, this is my preference with fried rice.  I got a one item and ordered the string bean chicken.  It was made with garlic black bean sauce and white meat chicken.  I really liked it, although it would have been better had the strings been removed from the beans.  But then again it's only $8 and I wouldn't want them to have to increase the price due to all of that extra labor.  
I'll be back...maybe even today ...
author: Emma H.

description:
This place offered food that was edible. It's really close to my office so I figured I owed it a chance after walking by for almost a full year. 

It was packed when I stepped in this past blustery Tuesday afternoon. I ordered the Rare Beef Pho with chow fun noodles (special request) which was around $9.50, scoped out a little table in the back, and popped in a podcast while I waited. The space is cozy, I guess, but the open door to Battery made the place a little on the freezing side. 

My giant, steaming bowl arrived a few minutes later. Much to my satisfaction, they have fish sauce and swiftly brought me extra jalepenos. Now to the food. 

I must keep it real, folks: I have had better pho. The noodles were great, but it's relatively easy to find a pho spot that offers chow fun noodles. The meat was not as fresh as it could have been, already tough and cooked through by the time it hit the table. The broth was on the sweet side and had a ton of lemongrass in it. If I had to do it all over, I probably would have taken a pass and just grabbed something else. Maybe Chinese / Hawaiian BBQ is their strong suit? But hey, I tried, and I don't think this review will dent their seemingly devout client base.
author: Crystal C.

description:
This is a pretty tiny Chinese place in the FiDi area that has a rice/noodle + 1 to 2 item plate option buffet all ready to serve, or menu items that can be ordered and prepared while you wait. Many customers seemed to choose the latter, more notably the udon and noodle soups. We went with the buffet option and each ordered a 1 item + rice plate which was served quickly and we grabbed a small table in the corner as the place was filling up quickly with people for pick up orders as well as dine-in. 

For vegetarians, there's not really a lot of options available on the buffet table, but you'll find one or two items if you're not too picky. I picked the spicy tofu with a side of fried rice and while it was definitely on the spicy side, it was good, a sizeable portion, and a decent price. 

If you're looking for something quick and inexpensive, and aren't a fan of the generic Chinese takeout style, this isn't a bad option if you're in the area.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Too much MSG. Got a headache after eating there yesterday. Had the fish with black bean sauce.
author: Elaine T.

description: Their Chinese Noodles are good, good soup base.  A bit pricey for Asian food, however we are in the middle of SF downtown....  Service, not so hot.  No sympathy when they get the order wrong and you have to wait and extra 10 minutes...   I would come here for their soups, buffet is decent with a bit on the salty side....  Owner is very pleasant but he is so busy, he doesn't notice when things go wrong with the orders....
author: Betty L.

description: I'll go back sometimes I guess, just because I like imperfect food. I had the 3-item takeout box, with Vegetable Chow Fun (not as good as the house chow fun from Lotus House in berkeley), Honey Chicken (meh, not terrible), Broccoli Beef (they didn't give me much beef but it was really good beef and fairly raw broccoli, which is good imo), Sesame Chicken (which is a bit weirdly flavored). Maybe is too authentic for me?
author: Lauren H.

description:
I work a block away and have been eating at 77 Chinese 2-3 times/month for over a year. Yes, they could use some rebranding (77 Chinese and Vietnamese) but their food is consistently good and cravable in my opinion. My go-tos.

** Basil Chicken: good basil and garlic flavor, moist chicken (I've never had fatty or gristly chicken here).

** Hot & Sour Soup: some of the best I've had and it's full of egg, tofu, bamboo, peppers, and spice!! I'd say a handful of times there's been a one-offs where the flavor isn't up to its usual standard.

** Eggplant with Tofu: delicious sweet, sour, and spicy flavor. I don't order this if I get the Hot & Sour soup since the flavor profiles are so similar. Delicious vegetarian option.

** Egg Roll: deliciously crisp. I think they only serve egg rolls with meat. Verify before you order, vegetarians.


Tips:
- If you're ordering an item "to order," call or Eat24 and place your order so you don't have to stand around for 5-15 mins waiting for it.
- You can get steam table items without rice/noodles, if you want. Save some money and leave out the carb temptation if that's your thing.
- If you're eating lunch there, bring a sweater because they usually leave their front door open and it can get chilly in there.


It's also one of the few places in the FiDi that stays open past 5PM that isn't a sandwich or burrito place woo!! I have yet to try the pho but I will!
author: Nas M.

description:
Blame Canada. Blame it on the Bossa Nova. Blame it on the Boogie. But for Pete's sake, don't blame me for having a once-in-a-while craving for won ton soup on a wintry workday when the cold breezes cause a chill both indoors and out. I had a hope that 77 Chinese Cuisine may offer a good one, but that hope was dashed when I attempted to order the $6.50 Won Ton Noodle Soup with a request for extra won ton. When I went to the buffet line with my order, the woman kept looking at me like I was speaking in tongues. I repeated my order as another woman kept shoveling food onto a plate for the customer behind me. She said rather inexplicably "Chow Mein".

No, I repeated, "Won Ton Noodle Soup with Extra Won Ton". She just waved me off to wait over to the side. For ten minutes, I had no idea what I was going to get. Meanwhile, people who came after me were getting their orders without hesitation. I kept seeing an unattended bowl wrapped in a plastic bag at the order window. Could it be mine? No, another customer got it.  Finally my bowl arrived, I paid $8.50 presumably for the "extra won ton". Lack of trust motivated me to open the bag to see if I was going to be stuck with a bowl of chow mein. Nope, it looked like the right order. Back in the office, I attempted to slurp it, but it bun my tun (see photo). And so ends my harrowing story of miscommunication and misperception.

FOOD - 2 stars...I bun my tun
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...a lunch room for the indiscriminate eater of greasy-looking Chinese food
SERVICE - 2 stars...puzzled and puzzling
TOTAL - 2 stars...no special orders please...and feel free to blame it on the boogie
author: Ed U.

description: I love this place when I'm feeling sick. I come here to get Jook (rice porridge) because it's comforting. On a cold day, I like their Soup Noodles, both the Chinese and Vietnamese versions. The Jook is delicious and reminds me of when my Pau Pau would make Jook for me. It's thick in consistency and has real big chunks of fish, chicken or pork with thousand year old egg. Even the egg come in big pieces. They add green onion and ginger to the Jook which makes it tastier especially when my throat is itchy. The portions are huge and it's only $6.50 for Chicken Jook or $7.50 for Fish Jook. I also like the cooked entrees and my office occasionally orders from here. Their Hawaiian BBQ is fine too but I prefer the Chow Fun, Meat with String Beans, and things of that nature. When we order for delivery, the owner delivers it himself and he's never been late. We always bet on what time he'll arrive and he's somehow not early nor late but RIGHT ON TIME! I service is very friendly and I should mention I order my food in Cantonese though their English is fine. Even my white husband orders in Cantonese here and they practice with him vs. the rude ladies at Lee's (another review, another time).
author: Jen L.

description:
When the weather starts to get nippy and warmth is what I seek, I usually come here for won ton soup.  They serve one of the more tastier won ton and chicken broth in the FiDi area.  It's not the best but it'll do.

They have your typical selection of hot food ready for the picking.  I've tried it a few times but they are not memorable enough to mention.  Otherwise, I'd recommend the won ton soup, it's made to order and always nice and hot to take the chill off the bones.
author: Jenny T.

description: Definitely hits the spot for some relatively cheap Chinese food. Decently priced lunch option that's really fast. I really like the basil chicken. Portions are really generous -- they'll hook you up. The workers are really nice too - sometimes I've gone as late as 2:30 and when a lunch option was out, they offered to make a new serving fresh for me.
author: Joshua J.

description:
The concept has potential and the location is great. The beef is mystery meat and VERY greasy. Many things are battered and deep fried. Not even cheap. Stay away.

I much prefer Panda Express.
author: Andrew K.

description: Just saw that this place has a poor food safety score, bottom 5% locally. I've eaten here, but never again. Thanks, Yelp for the FYI.  Patrons have a right to know these things.
author: JustMe D.

description: Tried the pho here for lunch and it was terrible. Soup base was VERY SALTY, portion was very small (I guess for an average person it would be okay but not enough for me), noodles were overcooked, beef wasn't very good. I would not recommend coming here for pho.
author: Sherry Y.

description: Flavor-less chow mein, and the Basil Chicken I tried, had the same texture as beef jerky.  First time a non-chain Chinese restaurant made me regret passing up Panda Express. The service was cheerful -- maybe compensating for the poor food quality.
author: Rajeev P.

description:
Not bad Pho for a Chinese/Hawaiian place.  LoL

The broth was pretty good....order the Spicy pho, it's pretty good.  Even the buffet styled Chinese food didn't look bad.  Totally unpretentious and prices were right.

I'd definitely come back.
author: Edward M.

description:
As a huge fan of Pho, I discovered this places as part of my Pho places hunt. I found their chicken Pho is far better(though it's not the best) compared to other financial district places. Quantity is little disappointing though, I feel
Hungry after two hours of having their pho :(
Andddd....their fried rices:
Tried almost all of their chicken fried verities, but didn't like anyone. Though they are huge in quantity, too oily and have plenty of rice with very less meat.
author: Venkat K.

description: This restaurant is just OK. Food quality and taste is 6/10. Location is convenient since it is in the middle of the financial district. Good choice for some quick chinese food out of a Panda Express. During Lunch time it gets very packed (like always at financial). And finally, I think they should change their name to 77 Chinese period, no more Hawaiian food exist in there.
author: H C.

description: Excellent Pho!  Always good and does not make me sleepy. So they must be holding the MSG.
author: Scott R.

description: I am so disappointed. Being from Oahu, when I walked by the Hawaiian BBQ sign, my mouth immediately started to water. I quickly ordered the bbq chicken plate with mac. DONT EVER ORDER this! The Mac tasted like wet cardboard - it wasn't creamy and tasty but instead bland, watery and chalky if that's a way to describe the consistency :( chicken was loaded with sodium, had to toss this entire plate. Looks can be deceiving  :(
author: Lachmin S.

description: No actual Hawaiian barbecue at this restaurant. Their menus been changed to say it's Chinese and Vietnamese cuisine. Currently waiting for my sweet and sour chicken lunch plate so I have nothing to say about quality yet!
author: Natalie F.

description:
If you are optimizing and speed and convenience as opposed to the food, this will work for you. 

I got the 2 item combo with 1/2 chow fun, 1/2 rice, tofu veggies and the grilled chicken. The chicken was a little dry but was the best part. The chow fun was too oily and the tofu and rice were pretty bland. The people who work here are pretty nice and it is a quick in and out.
author: Sunil R.

description: If you like Pho, don't have it at this Chinese restaurant!  The broth was lacking in everything. And oily.  The Vietnamese rolls, were served with shredded lettuce.  What am I am suppose to do with that?  Everything was questionable here!  But for pho, my standards are high.  Stick to Asian briber goods in downtown Oakland and Los Angeles for good pho!
author: Septima M.

description:
This place has a lot of potential to be a great chinese fast food joint ... potential

Recently ordered: BBQ chicken hawaiian bbq plate about $9 after tax

I had no where to go and no idea what I wanted and i stumbled on this 77 chinese & hawaiian bbq spot. OH man i regretted it after i ate a piece of that "BBQ" chicken that they might as well call soy sauce chicken because of how SALTY it was.

Chicken was way too salty. Next, rice was cheap rice (i can taste the quality cuz i'm asian) and the macaroni salad was not very good, pretty bland.

For the price I paid that was almost $9, I expected better tasting food for that price. Unfortunately, the taste was not there and the price is inflated to fit the FIDI prices. 

I dont think I want to come back...
author: Kenny L.

description: Went here on a cold and rainy day when I was craving pho and as it turns out, on my way to another restaurant that serves pho (the name of this place doesn't suggest it but there are many pho options). I wasn't disappointed. The wait was about 10 minutes, so not super fast for to-go food, but they packed up my pho perfectly- with the soup separate from the meat, sprouts, basil and jalapeno- and even a small packet of hoisin sauce and Sriracha with a napkin, spoon, fork and chopsticks. I ate the whole damn thing and now I'm in a slightly uncomfortable but completely satisfied food coma. Also, now the rain is gone. Coincidence? I think not.
author: Mar C.

description: Actually this place isnt bad since they added the Viet menu... definitely recommended for the FiDi workers... this is the closest to Clement or San Jose viet food you can find... granted you can tell it wasnt made by Viet people... tolerable and cheap... a must visit...
author: Nathan D.

description: One of my favorite lunch spots having worked in the Financial District for 10+ years--the owner is SUPER nice and courteous, and staff is friendly, too.  Sometimes I ask the owner for suggestions, and he'll customize my lunch entree based on what's good and fresh (i.e. salmon).  Other times I run out of ideas for lunch and he'll "surprise" me, and what's served is always delicious and price is reasonable to say the least.  I highly recommend this place for either dine-in or to-go order.  77 is our staple that we come back again and again.  :D
author: Vicky H.

description:
The restaurant across the street wasn't cooking anything as they were revamping their menu so decided to eat here for a quick lunch. It's set up like Panda Express, but it's definitely far superior. 

If you like spicy food, then you'll love this! The vegetarian fried rice is phenomenal but I wouldn't get the chicken fried rice or chicken chow mien, the veggie fun mien is way better! 

I love their deep fried spare ribs, but if you can't handle the heat, don't try it. Their eggplant tofu is really delicious, but I wasn't impressed with their honey chicken or sesame chicken, actually don't even go for it. Their green beans though, wow! This place really does vegetarian well, but their meat dishes are disappointing.

So for a vegetarian stand point, i would recommend this place to everyone. Unfortunately, if you enjoy meat, this might not be the best place for it.
author: Matthew M.

description:
After deliberating with myself for nearly an hour of whether or not I should try this place out for lunch, I decided to come by. 

I recently had my wisdom teeth taken out, so for the past few days I've only been eating soft foods. I was particularly fiending for some good congee, so this place popped up in my yelp search and I decided to go for it. After reading various reviews of this place, I pictured an unkempt restaurant with subpar-looking food. I was pleasantly surprised, as it was nice & clean, and tons of steam were coming off the hot food bar (not self serve, fyi). I was promptly greeted by the gentleman at the front, and he put in my order right away. It took under 10 minutes, which isn't too bad of a wait. I also expected it as well, since it was a porridge made to order. 

Once I got back to my office, I opened up the huge steaming bowl of congee. Classic look, classic fragrant smell, and classic taste. At first pass of the spoon, I thought they were being pretty frugal with the chicken - I barely saw any! But as I kept eating, I noticed there was more than I thought. It's kind of a comfort food for me, as Filipinos have a similar dish called arroz caldo/lugaw. 

It's a great sized meal for $7.45, and I would definitely come back to order it again. I'll also consider trying their chinese fast food, as it smelled pretty damn good too. Glad I tried this place out.
author: Eduardo R.

description: I came in to try the buffet. I had noodles with two sides which included generals chicken and beef and broccoli. The food was tasty and priced accordingly. If you are in a rush and just want some fast Chinese food I am sure that you can find something here to suit your palate.
author: Charles B.

description: Found a cooked cockroach in my white rice. I'm the same guy who says a good Chinese restaurant has dirty floors. But I think I found my limit. No cockroaches cooked with my rice please.
author: Joon L.

description:
One star for the friendly service.
The food,on the other hand,was terrible and mainly because it was cold.
Not hot,not warm,but COLD.And believe me,cold curry chicken is utterly gross.
Would not recommend it to a friend. -.-
author: Mike M.

description:
My buddy Gialisa comes here and the trick is to order off the menu rather than line up for the food troughs. 

She gets the prawns with fresh veggies in a garlic sauce and the BBQ pork chow fun, with the basil chicken rice when it's on the board. 

I have to say, I love the shrimp dish. It's light, and the veggies are crisp, and the sauce is garlicky. I liked the basil chicken fried rice - not to greasy. The chow fun is heavy, although the flavors are good, but very siesta inducing.  I have also had the beef with eggplant - not sure what's in the sauce, but if I were eating alone I may have licked the plate :)

It's pretty darn cheap too, which is a huge plus!
author: Mi M.

description: I was craving for congee yesterday and I am so happy that I gave it a try at this place. I had the pork and century egg congee. It is very authentic and the portion was very decent for $7-$8. I am getting it again today!
author: Aviva Z.

description: Came here for the 1st time on this really cold day craving soup. I saw that the restaurant was rated 3 stars, but decided to give it a shot anyway. I ordered the Wor Wonton Soup for $8.25. It was a generous amount of noodles, cabbage, wonton, & other meats. Granted that I am a small girl, I felt it could be shared with another person. I've definitely had better wonton soup, but I was going for convenience & didn't expect to be blown away with the taste, especially here in the Financial District. The lady that greeted me & took my order was very pleasant, always with a smile on her face when speaking to a customer.
author: Katrina R.

description:
I had the spicy tofu and fish in black bean sauce that cost ~$9. I felt that the core food (fish and tofu) could have been a bit less cooked as it seemed quite soft as if a part of the gravy itself. But I liked the combination of spices.
I hadn't had Chinese in a while and so I quite liked this place. Even otherwise I would rate this place above average. The ambiance is not that great and typical of a regular street side Chinese restaurant and the dishes are laid out to choose from. $7.25 for 1, $825 for two and $9.25 for three so good value for money.

Food - 3.5
Ambiance - 3
Service - 3 (Didn't order anything special)
Value for money - 4.5
author: Kunal R.

description:
I don't know about their Chinese food, but the Hawaiian short ribs I ordered was possibly the worst "hawaiian food" I've had. The meat was stringy, fatty (and not the delicious kind), and low quality in general. I enjoy salty foods, but not when salt is the main flavor. 

Oh, and they replaced my macaroni &cheese with giant pieces of broccoli...why??Thanks for the meal, 77 Chinese Cuisine & Hawaiian BBQ. I hope we never meet again. The only good thing is that they have a great website: http://www.77chinesesf.com/
author: Sijia W.

description:
This is review of lunch from 77 Chinese Cuisine & Hawaiin BBQ.

We were walking to Chipotle to pick up lunch.  We walked by this place and just decided to give it a try.

We went for the basic pick your rice, pick your dishes combos  I had a three piece combo steamed rice.  I selected Mongolian Chicken, Sesame Chicken,and Pepper Beef.

This was all very average.  I was surprised though the Pepper Beef had enough peppers to give it some kick.   The Mongolian Chicken was ok.  The sesame chicken would could have been a bit more crispy.  The portion was large and a good value.

http://tinyurl.com/5tom9d3

I found the staff to be very friendly.  The service was fast.  My meal was under $10.  The ambiance is plain.  For me, it is more of a place for carry-out.

Overall, this is a place you go if you work near it, have very little time for lunch, and want a lot of food for just a few greenbacks.

I may go there again.  It is very close to my office.  However, it is not the kind of place you would walk more than a block of two for.  Because, in the FiDi, if you walked three blocks to it, you would walk by a number of places that are better.
author: Mark D.

description: They sell pho here now.  Best in this part of the Financial District and only place to go for it.  Don't bother anywhere else.  Hands down...
author: Mark M.

description:
I order a lunch special of Mongolian Beef. Def more rice then the entree. They are very slow. My co worker order Hawaiian BBQ and it took almost 25mins for them to give him his order. They encourage you to use cash because you get a free appetizer. I didnt get mine nor did my friend.  Service was def a downer food. Food was just ok.

Food- 4
Service 1
author: Kyle W.

description:
Service here is really slow and inefficient if you order at the register. I had to remind them that I ordered food before they started making it. Ended up waiting about 40 minutes before I got the food. The food itself was okay, not great. 

I'd recommend going somewhere else unless you get in the buffet line (not sure how that tastes)
author: Kevin H.

description:
The FiDi has lots of great food... but for chinese food, it's lacking. I'm spoiled by the stores on Clement, so that's probably where my bias comes in. 

77 Chinese Cuisine & Hawaiian BBQ isn't too bad. The prices run a little higher than I expect from a chinese place, but let's get real, they can charge whatever they want because there's not that many great places nearby, even with a Lee's next door. 

Service is quick and that's a good thing as long as you can overlook the sometimes rude/lackluster service. What do you really expect? It's a chinese combo place! The quick service factor gives them a gold star in my book. It should go something like this: 

"Next?"
"2 item combo, with fried rice"
"Uh huh" slaps food into box...
"salt & pepper pork" 
"uh huh" slaps food into box...
"beef brocolli" 
"uh huh" slaps food into box, closes it up, pushes it down to the cashier. 

Done and done. 

I like their salt and pepper pork and their beef and brocolli. The usual run of the mill chinese options. Haven't tried much else. You can ask for brown rice too. They don't have it on display but they have it ready to go in the back. 

I've ordered their hawaiian loco moco. They forgot to put in fine print, it's chinese style. Their gravy is garlicky, their hamburger meat is obviously frozen. It comes with steamed brocolli. And yet, whatever, it's really good hangover food. If you want Hawaiian food, walk down to L&L. If you want hawaiian food chinese style, they got it. 

If you're in the mood for greasy chinese food, come here. Don't set your expectations high, but isn't that pretty obvious when you walk in?
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Been here a couple times for the hot food bar.  Quality is fine.  Can't complain about it from the type of place it's coming out of.  Relatively cheap for the area.

My main gripe with the place? I order the 3 item box, yet they stuff more than half of it with noodles everytime.  The meat's at the end of the bar so they can use as little of it as possible. Tried to order 2 meat items to get more meat, and they end up just giving me less of each (3 pcs of batter heavy 5spicechicken, and just 1 piece of grilled chicken???).

I'm a big guy so I eat a lot.  Maybe this is the wrong place for me, but I feel like the service is stingy.  Seriously, quit swindling your own brethren.
author: Conan T.

description: Right now, my favorite lunchtime place.  large menu selection, good authentic quality, fast service, and cheap!  What else you need for a workday lunch?
author: Snoopy D.

description:
Ever pass a place a million times and never go in? I did that to this place... when I was hankering for a new place, I walked right in here since I always see the place packed for lunch.  Boy am I ever glad I did!

I've been here several times since.  I don't do the hot food bar... just not my thing. I have ordered several of their dishes to go, fresh made from their menu.  The service is FAST, the folks friendly and the dishes? DELICIOUS.

My all time fave is the pan-fried noodles. How can you go wrong with both crunchy, soft noddles with gravy?!? You can't go wrong. Great place downtown for a fast, delicious lunch. Thanks!
author: Hitomi B.

description:
I was sooooo excited to have found a chinese place that has jook/rice porridge close to my work! They have a variety of jook too, chicken, pork with preserved egg, seafood and veggie. It was reasonablly priced at 5:96 and the portion was huge. Granted that it wasn';t the best jook i've ever had- Chinatown is much much better, it was still ok, a little too salty for my taste but not bad. 

They also have a variety of chinese dishes(beef with broccoli, orange chicken), noodle soups (won ton noodle soups, hot and sour soups) and dimsum ( shrimp and pork dumplings, pork buns and etc. )that i can't wait to come back and try. Most dishes range from $5-$8 and that is super cheap for food in FIDI. The owners are cantonese and they are super nice! 

Tip- I would order from the menu since those are made to order rather than ordering from the steam table  which is the  pre cooked food where you order like panda express style. 1 entree, 2 entree and etc. 

Overall I am very happy to have more asian options that is close to my work. YAY!!!!!!
author: Tenny W.

description:
It's a slightly nice break from the sub-par Asian food in the area. San Francisco is a great place for food, but for some reason working around this area I exhausted my options pretty quickly. 

This place is great if you want something quick and the service was great and friendly.
author: Justin C.

description:
"Can  I please get two sirachas and hoisin sauce please?"

Lady-"OK"

She drops in one.

"Excuse me can I have 2 please?"

Lady- "OK"

*REPEAT*

She doesn't drop in anything.

*REPEAT*


"Excuse me, can I please get a container i'll just scoop my own sauce. Thank you" 

She grabs a container.

Hands me my food. I check over my stuff, container is in there--no lid. WTF????? Checks for condiments, still one siracha. OK I GIVE UP. BYE!

#23 was good and flavorful. Cheap lunch for fi-di.

They use MSG. Who doesn't now and days, currently guzzling water.
author: Thao L.

description:
Seriously, I'm torn between one and two stars, not a dilemma that works to their advantage. I decided to be generous and bump them up from 1.5 stars. I'm no food snob, and I don't claim to have a sophisticated palette. Yet, I don't have a great deal of tolerance for cheap food that tastes even cheaper. Just because the food is cheap does not mean you're not actually paying for it a different way. I mean, if you have to spend time away from work in the restroom doing some combination of a #1, #2, and #3, like I did, arguably you're losing money...the company feels it, the client feels it and ultimately the economy feels it. It's clear 77's cheap Chinese fast food deserves some blame for the state of the economy.   

Enough of my tirade and on to my qualms. All fried items I tried were greasy. The sauced items were dripping in sauce that was obviously loaded with sugar and probably MSG. This makes Panda Express look like a Michelin rated establishment.  And making Panda look good (Express, not Pablo Sandoval) is quite a feat in and of itself.  Now I have to figure out why I've spent this much time and space on this restaurant. I'm done.
author: Angel S.

description:
Thanks to my mom who cooks Chinese food almost daily, I RARELY ever crave Chinese food, and when I do, it's something she doesn't cook: dim sum. 

I've come here a few times because my coworker orders noodle soups from here often. I once needed noodle soup for lunch and came here to order their won ton mein. That satisfied my craving and tasted like almost all other Chinese BBQ type places that serve won ton mein. The next time I came back was because I really wanted jook, it was a foggy 55 degrees outside, and it was close to my office. I placed an order for jook w/chicken but specifically asked if the chicken was shredded (they confirmed it was), so I ordered a shredded chicken jook with NO ginger. The girl at the counter repeated my order back to me and asked if it was ok to add onions, which I said was ok. She repeated my order again: jook with shredded chicken and onions, but no ginger. YES! After returning to my desk, I noticed my jook was made with the same chicken they use for most other dishes here. That would be fine except that it's the stir-fry kind of chicken. Needless to say, it was NOT shredded. Also, they cut their ginger in strands and they were found throughout my jook. I took a fork and fished as many strands as I could out. Typically, I wouldn't really care that it came this way but she told me otherwise. Also, if I was allergic, I'd be pretty upset that my order came exactly how I asked for it NOT to. The jook itself tasted fine with a little salt added, but I was disappointed with the chicken and ginger. 

My coworker, a regular here, went to order his food right after I returned to the office and he told me he mentioned this error to them. The girl at the counter told him she doesn't remember anyone ordering jook that day. Sigh.

Their jook and won ton mein taste just fine and will satisfy your craving, but it is disappointing that even if you are specific with your order, they will tell you they can honor it and just completely ignore it. Unacceptable.
author: Stella C.

description:
I came here wanting to get some Hawaiian BBQ. 

Unfortunately, they only CATER Hawaiian BBQ.

Their chinese food was "okay".

I got the bbq pork with scrambled egg over rice.

It was good, but I've had better.


Their prices are reasonable.
author: Daniel C.

description: Fast cheap horrible food. Bbq chicken tasted like it was made last week, the walnut chicken a few days ago and chow fun yesterday. At least the water was clean.
author: Sasha O.

description:
So I was walking by on my lunch time walk (I normally bring a healthy lunch then walk during lunch) and as per usual I see "Dim Sum" at any but the most sketchy locale and I want something.  (It's one of my weaknesses)

I didn't have time to order anything fresh but there seemed to be pretty fresh Shui Mai on the steam table.  

Me: "I'll have 2 Shui Mai"
Girl: "Thats it?"
Me: "Yep"
She gave me them in a wax paper bag...kinda weird.  Asked if I wanted soy or chili (how is that going to work with a wax paper bag and no eating implements?) I think people do not normally just order 2 Shui Mai.  I was worried for a minute until she said, "$1.50"  

SWEET!  And they were pretty large (a pingpong ball and a half each) and they had tons of pieces of whole shrimp and were hot and soft (not at all dry/crispy on the outside or just above room temperature like some cheap shui mai/dim sum.) They were flavorful and very satisfying.  I munched on them all the way back to the office very happily. 

So I really have no idea about them other than I had damn good shui mai for $1.50 completely spontaneously.  Which rocks.
author: Susan C.

description: THis used to be my go-to for HK style beef chow fun. Perfectly and appropriately prepared, dry, with green onions and bean sprouts.  I worked away from the FiDi last couple years and looks like this place, like Hong Kee & Kim few blocks up, has changed hands to Viet owners.  The HK chow fun was not prepared right, and was a soupy mess with bok choy, carrots (!?), and some beef.  I was so disappointed. The buffet/combo items still look OK, but I've never ordered from that so I can't really opine.  If you are going for real HK chow fun, skip 77.
author: Joel M.

description: Purchased the sea-food pan fried noodles. The food was pretty fresh for a Chinese/Hawaiian restaurant.  If you are expecting a 5 star restaurant then go somewhere more expensive. The food is definitely better than Lee's deli which is right next door.
author: David N.

description: I was pleased with this spot, very close to my work.  I was on the way to Sapphire on Sacramento and figured I'd give this one a shot.  I had the chicken fried rice with with sesame chicken and bbq chicken.  It was very good quality.  The breading was not overdone on the sesame chicken and quality of the chicken was good on both.  classy serving tray.  only negative is the food was not hot enough, or else it would be a 5.
author: Marc S.

description:
I came in here hungry. Their portions are big, but not top quality. I ordered chicken fried rice, which was bland, pot stickers, which were definitely on the dry side, salt and peppered spare ribs (should be renamed to oily and crunchy spare ribs), and barbecue chicken which was, in my opinion, way too fatty.

Needless to say, the best part of this meal was the Arizona iced tea I ordered to wash this all down with.
author: Isaac D.

description:
I'm Yelping about their made to order food (I'm not big on steam table food ala Panda.  Not to say that it isn't good but it's not me).  Anyhoo, I've been circling this place for awhile.  

Today I finally dropped in to take a look see.  Glanced at the steam table but nothing stood out for me.  I asked the owner (he is (was?) the owner of Happy Donuts down the block) if they make chow mein that was on the menu.  He said they did.

I ordered a seafood chow mein.  They gave me this huge order (in a round take out container).  Chow mein is actually pretty good (not too greasy and not too salty).  They were also generous w/ the seafood (shrimp, scallops, calamari some fish).  

They are one of the very few FiDi places that do made to order chinese food.  

Staff is friendly and courteous (service with a smile!).  I also got a free pop with my order.

Not bad for $7.87 (considering I get to spread this meal out into 2 lunches!).
author: Wendy H.

description:
YUM!  77 Chinese Cuisine and Hawaiian BBQ just opened last week by our office, and of course we had to try it!

The food is delicious, and in large enough portions that you will have enough for dinner if portion controlled (we didn't, and all ate everything in sight).

This place is an interesting mix of staple Chinese lunch plates and Hawaiian BBQ plates.  We all had the Hawaiian food today (Loco moco, BBQ mixed plate, BBQ chicken sandwich, etc.) so can't yet comment on the Chinese part, but the people behind the counter were all Chinese so I am sure if they can get the Hawaiian part right, the Chinese part has gotta be pretty tasty too.

The owner guy says free fountain soda for the month. :)

Oh, one of us is a preggo lady and the owner guy came by to offer her more food... it was so sweet!

Update:
We have been back many more times since.  We have now had the ready made Chinese food, the freshly made Chinese food, more Hawaiian food, and everything has been absolutely wonderful.  The owner and chefs will even make your scramble egg beef over rice the real Cantonese way (with really runny eggs) if you ask for it.

Definitely a five star experience for a lunch time find in FiDi.
author: Cindy C.

description:
I grabbed lunch here the other day and I can't say I was impressed. I got the spicy eggplant and sesame chicken. The spicy eggplant definitely wasn't spicy and I felt like it was just eggplant doused in sauce. The sesame chicken had the opportunity to be good, its deep fried, how can it not be? It wasn't. It was deep fried and flavorless. 

Definitely not going back.
author: Analisa S.

description:
Ordered the jook and dim sum combo which was pretty well priced for how much I got.  They made everything fresh which is great but we waited for around 20 minutes until we got our food (not so great).

The service was very friendly and we came in the morning so it was pretty empty except for the occasional walk-in.  

I definitely plan to come here when I'm craving a bowl of hot and fresh jook and I also want to try the other things on their menu but a tip for myself and for others: call in your order so you don't have to wait as long!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Great noodle dishes, especially their beef chow fun and singaporean noodles.  A plus that they also serve porridge and dim sum.  It's rare to find a decent cheap Chinese place in the FiDi, so this place is definitely in the weekly lunch routine.   Average price is $7-9.

The "panda express" style food they offer is too Americanized for me, so I usually steer clear of that and order the noodle dishes from the menu.

Super friendly staff too.
author: Yun W.

description:
i love the lunch to-go food. 

chicken walnut! is pretty good and pretty much the main reason why i come here :)
author: Jackz C.

description:
Fast food Chinese.... But where is the Hawaiian BBQ?! They didn't have any Hawaiian dishes that I noticed. 

As far as the Chinese food, it was similar to Panda express except worse. Options were limited and the dishes available looked old, soggy, and unappealing.

Ugh, such a disappointment!
author: Danny L.

description:
It pains me to do this. 
I've been coming here about once a week now since I discovered it. Not bc it's outstanding food, more that I'm OCD about what I eat. And at this juncture, I'm all about cheap chinese. I bring my diet-friendly lunch to work every day, but this is my once-a-week treat. So I know the staff, they know me... we get all happy and exchange pleasantries when I walk in. 
But seriously, over the past few weeks, portions are getting noticeably and ever-increasingly smaller, and EVERY time they make me ask for extra hot sauce, and begrudgingly give it up. They know I want this, bc they giggle after I ask. It gets embarrassing.
author: Meg W.

description:
This place is pretty awesome.  The combo of the hot bar with food ready to go.. as well as speedy service for special order food is rad.

The Chicken Katsu is SO good.  I love it.  Good food, good service.  Get down with the double 7.
author: Adam P.

description: I've been visiting this place for a few months now and not too impressed with the size of the portions that they serve.Almost as small as Lee's Deli or around $6.95 a pound.Not enough for my gut! Flavor is ok and service is ok too.The only reason I would recommend eating here is the service is fast.Try New Asia at the Galleria for HUGE portions and cheaper prices.
author: Buddha B.

description: I love this place.  I stumbled upon it while looking for lunch one week, and I've pretty much been back every week since.  The food is good, better than Lee's or Panda Express in my opinion.  The only thing is it can hit or miss sometimes, but overall I have been pleased.  The staff is great too, very friendly.
author: Nick O.

description:
I'm a bit of a snob when it comes to Chinese food..Chinese food restaurants are never my first choice when it comes to eating out since I am of Chinese descendence.  No one can cook better than my gramma or mom!

The only thing good about this place is that they are open past most places in the financial district if you get hungry.. it is somewhat of my last resort.  I find the steam table food a bit bland and I find that, ordering from the menu, the portions are a bit chinsy.

As far as the Hawaiian bbq, I'd rather walk a few extra blocks for L&L on Kearny because their mac salad kicks ass (but not as much as Ono)!  The people are nice...
author: ThirtyTwo P.

description: The pho I order was pretty weak. Three slices of over cook beef, even though it's rare beef pho, it's small, not that good. But they were fast. So my assumption is their Chinese food is the main draw, not pho.
author: Sandie Y.

description: You walk in, immediately see it's all Asians eating in this tiny place. At least when i walked in. That just tells me, this is good quality cooking. Always knew this place existed, but never set foot until today. Wanted a hawaiian short rib plate but there was no short ribs today, so went with a mixed plate of BBQ Beef, BBQ chicken and they gave katsu chicken in place of no short rib. Katsu was amazing, lightly breaded/fried and chicken melted in my mouth. I quickly finished that for lunch. Only ate a bite of each BBQ meat to try, but will save that for dinner. Scoop of mac salad was good too. Not bad for $9.25 total, every thing was fresh. What made the experience even better was one of the regulars walked in. I said hello to her, calling her Aunty as i noticed her Hawaiian heirloom jewelry, she smiled and said Aloha. She also told me which dished were 'ono'. Yep im coming back here! IO noticed they was eggplant tofu and a good mix of other fresh looking veggies ready to be eaten by the FiDi lunch masses.
author: Gwen K.

description: Ok service, bad food. Food wasn't fresh at all and tasted old. There are better chinese cuisines in a quarter mile radius out there.
author: Lijo L.

description:
The owner of this restaurant is related to the owner of Happy Donuts down the street. Funny that the service and the lunch menu is so different from each other. 

When craving a variety of Chinese inspired dishes, this is the place to go! You can order select items that the kitchen will cook up fresh or you can order from the steam table. 

I mostly order the 3 item plus rice to go from the steam table for $8. The steam table  has over 10 different dishes ranging from vegetarian (tofu and vegetables) to meat heavy (Peking spare ribs) and mixed in between (broccoli beef).

It's fast, convenient and filling. They give you a lot of food in the to-go containers. So much that I usually split the meal into two and save the other portion or my lunch the next day.
author: Christine T.

description: 30+ min for vermicelli. They probably forgot about my order. Disappointed, 50% more expensive than Tulan for worse quality/smaller portions,  100% won't go back.
author: Daniel W.

description: Is this the best Chinese food in SF? No, but it does the trick. The staff is nice, they give you your food fast, and their portions are perfect for lunch.
author: Abena O.

description: I really like the Mongolian beef here. The first time I had it, it was ok. The next couple of times was really good. (Had a good amount of spiciness.) But the last two times I was there the Mongolian beef was so spicy I could not even finish it. I had to leave the rest for my fiance to finish (he loves spicy food.) Next time, I'll have to see if I can get the level of heat reduced, but that makes me nervous since the other times I have been, it was not nearly as spicy. Anyway, I really like it here and the pricing isn't too bad.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Reasonably priced and  decently portioned. What more could you ask for in the FiDi!?!? I've had the fish, chow mein, and kung pao chicken  from their steam table. It's pretty good considering it's located in the FiDi. 

I had a craving for Hot & Sour soup today since I've been feeling under the weather. The soup was served in a container that was reasonably portioned. It came out to $6.50, which isn't too bad. It definitely hit the spot!
author: Candice H.

description: Two choices: call ahead for an order ($7-$9/plate), or wait in line for buffet style (2 items ~$8-$9).  This (mostly) Chinese food is better than the small-chain deli next door, because it's cooked in smaller batches so has a lot of turnover - typically hot and fresh.  I've order the black bean beef chow fun, and it was tasty with plenty of beef - but too many onions.  From buffet, I've had salt & pepper pork chops, kung pao, black bean green beans.  All have been decent to good.  I go there more often than I check in...
author: Chris D.

description:
Blech.

To the guy who called out the mac salad: I thought u were being a little high maintenance, but I just tried it and it really does suck.  It's actually sweet, like they put sugar in it.  Rest assured that no mac salad in Hawaii tastes like that.

The rest of the meal was not much better. The mahi mahi was heavily breaded, and slimy in the middle, definitely frozen beforehand. Pretty sick.  The tartar sauce they serve it with is equally sweet like the mac salad.  The rice was edible, but dry and didn't stick together. It also comes with "tofu soup" which is gelatinous and semitanslucent.  My friend said he could taste the MSG, which for him was a positive, but I'm gonna have to take his word for it, I wasn't going to try it.

I asked the lady for teriyaki sauce, and she looked at me in puzzlement, then brought me chopsticks.

To be fair, my friend enjoyed his mixed plate (besides the mac salad), and the Chinese food looked OK.  But this is not a place you want to go for Hawaiian BBQ.  I wish Ono Hawaiian would open one closer to the FiDi.
author: Ryan U.

description: This is my usual fix on greasy chinese food.  Sadly, this will be my last visit as they raised the prices again.  I cant afford to pay $9.50 for 3 items. Call me cheap but now they're overpriced chinese food
author: Patrick C.

description:
The macaroni salad reminds me of an ex: initially sweet, but inconsistent, odd and not at all what I wanted.  If this represents mac salad in Hawaii, I'm glad it's not on my list of states to visit.  

The BBQ chicken isn't bad and only took a few minutes to make.  

Avoid steam tables everywhere, especially when the price is the same.
author: Jared L.

description:
This place sucks. Food that i had: chow mein, rice, broccoli beef, and sweet sour chicken... food tasted stale... flavors were not good

Service was good...
author: Sung B.

description: Ever have one of those day when you have no idea what to eat for lunch? That happens to me quite often.... I ended up wandering around found this place on a whim. i went in ordered a spam masubi and unagi fried rice. Portions are huge. I wasnt able to get to the fried rice. The owner and cashier lady are both super nice and eager to help/take your order. I'm a fan! Love the sweet customer service and food!
author: Linda P.

description:
"Hi how about next?" 

The lady that serves the food is very nice.  And surprisingly, the food isn't that bad.  It's a pretty good lunch spot on a stressful day, but not the best.

There are 2 fried rice choices, and they make a killer salt and pepper chicken and salt and pepper pork (or maybe it was beef).

But they also make honey walnut chicken.  My problem with the shrimp version of this dish is that it's always too expensive.  It's actually really nice to see chicken being used with a heep full of mayonaise and walnuts.  It's actually pretty good!  And it's cheap!
author: Adrian E.

description: Portions are HUGE!!!! Price is reasonable, food is alright. Gotta crave it to have it, wouldn't go out of my way to eat it.
author: Irma R.

description:
Yuck. Terrible service.  I ordered two sets of dim sum at around 3:15. No other customer was there, however, it took almost half an hour.  The strangest thing was that a customer came in, ordered, and got their food before ours was served.  I don't understand how warming up dim sum takes so long especially when it is a dead hour- not even lunch time.  When I finally complained about how long it was taking, I saw the chef start preparing the food! Don't waste your time or your money to eat here. I am totally dissatisfied with their service.
One more thing, when I told them I wanted to cancel my order, they gave me less than what I paid!
author: Christian E.

description:
To be brutally honest, I did not like the food here.

During tax season, our firm has our lunches catered by various places from around the Financial District/Chinatown.  One day, we got lunch from here.  I was really hungry and saw the spread from 77 in our kitchen and thought...wow, this looks really good...so I piled a bunch of everything on my plate:  mixed veggies w/ tofu, sweet and sour pork (which I thought was chicken by the looks of it), beef w/ broccoli, potstickers, chicken w/ string beans.  Well, let me tell you...everything looked way better than it tasted, except for the potstickers which were edible.
author: Michelle N.

description: I've been here twice and both times got the Chicken Katsu. I think their claiming "Hawaiian BBQ" a little loosely - they have about 6 hawaiian bbq items on their menu, but whatever. The Chicken Katsu is decent, as is the Katsu sauce. They also give a good amount. Macaroni salad was very bland - not my favorite. The worst part about this place is the wait. I must've waited 20min for my food and well, not so great as it was pretty empty there.
author: Junel S.

description: blan flavor, abrupt service and no labels indicating what is in the warming trays. So when you are choosing your combination, you have to ask the iritated server what everything is. and she gets iritated that you have to ask. WTF! Plus there is nothing Hawaiian about this place.
author: L v.

description: Beef Chow Fun noodles are good.  The dim sum/pot stickers are ok. The service is great.
author: Gennedy M.

description: Not amazing, but quite good considering the hordes of FiDi customers they serve. What is amazing is that they still remain polite while doing so. Worth checking out if you need fast food - they serve all the standards like chao mien, sesame beef, and fried pork chop.
author: Jason K.

description: I work around the corner. I tend to go to the same restaurant everyday until I get bored then still come a lot. The second day in a row I came here they skimp me hella hard with some small ass portions. They saved maybe 16 cents but will lose 8bucks per day for everyday I woulda came cuz I'm never going back. Wack ass overpriced wannabe panda express.
author: Edward S.

description: I have noticed that I have never seen a place on yelp with an avg rating of below 3.  As someone that wonders about the mysterious of the world, I wonder why this is the case.  If this place can't crack 3 stars, I guess it's just not possible.  I can't imagine anyone trying to argue this place is better than panda express, cooking up a bag of frozen chinese from safeway or just some cardboard stir fry.  If you eat this food and enjoy it, you apparently have no taste buds and I feel sorry for whatever accident caused this, maybe french kissing a boiling pot of water.
author: Brian G.

description:
Fast serviced chinese cuisine.

Had black bean fish and Kung pao prawn. They were all right. The staff looked nice.
author: Jay Y.

description:
Standing outside the office building, I was contemplating what I should gorge on for lunch. Just then my co-worker Dickson walked out and was heading out to lunch. Since I was also on lunch he asked if I would like to join him for some quick chinese food.

Sure why not, so after walking a good three blocks we came to 77.

Its pretty much like another regular panda express type of place, you have your choice of either getting items already lined out or you can order seperately. Like mongolian chicken or beef, curry chicken etc.
If you dont feel like chinese you can also opt for the Hawaiian BBQ, which includes the loco moco, chicken katsu, ribs etc.

I ordered the chicken katsu which was pretty good. Their macaroni sald is something I was most fond of. 
Dickson ordered the curry chicken. He prefers his chicken to have bones instead of pieces, but I think most people prefer to not have to pick out the bones and what not.

You can either eat in or take out, and prices are pretty good. My katsu was about 6.95 and Dicksons was about the same. So for a quick and easy lunch I could actually come here instead, service is good too. If your eating in they will bring the food to you instead of calling out your number.
author: phillip w.

description:
I keep hoping and hoping that the L&L on Kearny will reopen, but since it doesn't appear to be heeding my wishes, I've started coming here to fulfill my periodic cravings for Hawaiian. The meat here is tasty and tender, and no complaints about the macaroni salad. 
 
After I came here for the Hawaiian BBQ, I was tempted by the Chinese. I finally had some, and the verdict is mediocre. The chow mein is tasteless and gummy, my eggrolls were no longer crispy, and my Mongolian chicken was overwhelmed with sauce. 

Four stars for the Hawaiian, but three for the Chinese. I'm rounding up for the nice take out boxes and the seating
author: Ada T.

description: Had the HI BBQ platter here the other day and it was pretty good.  The meats were cooked well and the rice and the salad were pretty good.  $8 wasn't too bad of a price either.  I will say that it was pretty basic.  I would have liked it if they had some kind of good sauces or something that made it a little more exciting.  Again, everything was good, but nothing too special.  Next time I go back I'd like to try some of the Chinese foods.
author: Brian G.

description:
Craving for greasy, saucy Chinese, this is the place.  The 2 or 3 item selections are consistent.  They seem to always be running out of chow fun.   Ordering from the menu for plate dishes are not bad and priced a tad higher than B&M.  It's close, fast and fits the bill for decent volume of Chinese food.

Some seating, but not a place I'd rally a huge group +12 to meet.

Haven't tried the Hawaiian BBQ.  Doesn't look all that interesting.
author: I have something to say... A.

description:
Fast service and great food. With Lee's right next door it's an easy choice to eat at 77. Better food, no grease or msg.

Faves:
Fish black been
Mongolian chicken
Shrimp vegetable

Great value for good food!
author: Steve S.

description:
This place is literally right next door to my work building.  Usually I come here for a quick bite to eat of if I want Chinese food and I'm too lazy to take the 10 minute walk over to Chinatown.

They have a steam table style setup, but plenty of things on the menu that they'll cook for you right away.  I think it's a bit pricey for a steam table scooped lunch, but if you get something fresh off the wok, it's a decent price for the Financial District.

It gets pretty busy during lunch time, but I actually feel like that's the best time to go because all the food is fresh (since there's so many people getting everything).  What's an extra 5 minute wait, anyway?
author: Brent T.

description:
This is now going to be one of my regular restaurants.  I just had lunch here with one of my buddies from work, and I must say, WOW, you get surprisingly good food for a fairly cheap price ( under $7, especially in the Financial District in SF, it's a deal).  

Initially, I thought the Chinese & Hawaiian BBQ combo was weird, but when I got my order, I was pleasantly surprised that the two blended very well together.  They offer free delivery for orders over $25.  My buddy and I got there early (like 11:45ish), but the place was definitely getting a bit packed with people after 12.  I recommend trying the BBQ short ribs - Yum!!!. 

The staff are pretty friendly, and the place is nice and clean.  This is definitely one of the better "fast-food" Asian places I've had in a while - definitely worth trying out.
author: Minh V.

description: Last week I became incredibly ill from a confirmed case of salmonella poisoning. I have never been so sick in my entire life. 77 Chinese was the last thing I ate before I became ill and is the only food that could have been the culprit. Please please do not eat here.
author: Laura K.

description:
I left my building with no destination in mind, I started walking towards Lee's but luckily was distracted by the sign next door that said Hawaiian and Chinese so I thought what the hell, let's do this. Anyways I looked over the steam table and it looked decent, they had just brought out a new batch on broccoli beef and egg rolls so I asked for both and some fried rice. The portions are big and the food ok, not salty at all like most Chinese food. I will have to go back and try the Hawaiian bbq next. I also noticed the menu has dim sum items so I will have to try those too.
Note to owner:  Loco Moco on the bbq menu, not a really good name for your Spanish speaking customers.
author: La C.

description: Cool "I can take this home and reuse it" container. I grant them that. Cheap. I grant them that. But the rocks as seasoning? Way too many crunchy bits for me. Black, rocky, crunchy bits. Four of them that my teeth discovered. Crunchy. Ouchy.
author: Danielle L.

description: Always clean and friendly, reasonable prices.  Excellent kung pao calamari!
author: Dave M.

description: The trick is to order off the menu or any of the specials. Basil chicken rice, fish with okra in black bean sauce, basil tofu and the spicy chicken bowl are among the best in the city. The food in the pans out front is good if you get there early when it first comes out of the kitchen, otherwise stick to the menu.
author: David G.

description: Working in FiDi there are many choices for lunch that are good and economical.  For me, 77 stands above many other places in terms of value and quality, but they stand WAY above their competitors in customer appreciation/service.  I've been going to this place for years for my once or twice monthly dose of Hawaiian BBQ and am always amazed at how attentive and friendly everyone who works there is.  Keep up the good work!
author: Drew P.

description: How could I work in the FiDi for 8 yrs and not know that this place has fresh hot jook (nice sized portion) & a small but satisfying array of dim sum?  My goodness!  I'm glad I was walking down Battery St & saw the DIM SUM sign in the window.  They open as early as 7am and will take large dim sum orders to be delivered around 8:30am.  I keep telling myself I have to get over there to try their lunch items.  I love how helpful & honest the staff is.  And after my first visit they've remember me & have always been great to work with.  Since then I've catered dim sum from them once a week.  Its a relief to not have to make the trek to Chinatown for simple reliable eats.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
This place has one of the best wonton soup w/shrimp in the financial district.  

It's the only thing I have eaten from here.  The soup is cooked perfectly and it is not to oily.  Perfect for a rainy day!
author: Susie S.

description:
I haven't had their Hawaiian yet. I usually/normally/always get their seafood noodle soup with rice noodles or spicy spareribs and shrimps and vegetables with white rice. (I like to mix it up.) The spareribs have a kick. I don't know what it's cooked in and I see some chili seeds but these are much spicier than just a mere chili seed. YUM. The meat is also tender. They don't skip on the shrimp either. In a place like this, I expected a shrimp to be small, one of those that are only an inch or so, but their shrimps are called prawns at other places. As for the soup, it's not as heavily MSG'd as Lee's and is actually rather light.

-1 star because they get CRAZY during rushes. Between 11:45 to 1:30, it's almost a nonstop stream of customers. The longer the line, the more frantic the girls handling the register and food get. They whip back and forth like rabbits on crack. So, orders may get confused and you'll have to repeat yourself but it isn't too bad. It's actually kind of fun watching them. Like a trainwreck. But the girls are really nice. They try their best. I just want to tell a few of them to get elocution lessons. Accent + mush mouth = I don't understand!
author: Amy O.

description: I was looking for cheap, greasy, delicious Chinese food and this place was where I found it.  Perfect for if all you want is your Chinese food fix.  Decent prices and pretty tasty meals.
author: Cari P.

description:
Quick and efficient.  I've tried their black bean fish a few times, and each time, it was delicious.  However the chow fun has not been consistent;  it was soggy during my last visit.  

Generous portions that I have to remind myself not to eat the entire entree.  The friendly service adds to the welcoming atmosphere.
author: Jeannine L.

description: Cheap, easy and across the street from my office.  I only get the BBQ short ribs, they are pretty fn good and they make my hangovers go away.
author: Naveen S.

description:
I went here for the first time because I heard it was cheap, fast, and super delicious. I got Hawaiian instead of Chinese (next time I'll try the Chinese), which was only okay, but what blew me away was the service and hospitality. The main man (I think he's the owner) was so friendly and attentive and was basically running around doing everything. My dish was supposed to come with Mac Salad, but it didn't, and when I asked about it, he immediately ran (literally RAN) to the kitchen to get me a cup. He came back and told me they had run out, but to give him 2 minutes. He ran back to the kitchen and personally made a new batch of mac salad. How's that for service! And everything I heard was true. It was cheap, it was fast, and it was pretty good. Three hours later, I am still super full.

I'll definitely be going back to try the dim sum and the Chinese dishes. 

Oh, also, they don't use MSG, which says a lot because their food is flavorful without having to use that crap!
author: Erica M.

description:
I've only had their beef noodle soup, but it's good, it's fast, and it has a pretty good price point.  They waste too much in terms of utensils - I only need a spoon (and maybe chopsticks), but no fork or soy sauce.  Soy sauce?  

Staff is friendly enough and, it seems, eager.
author: Evan G.

description:
I work at Market and 1st so this place is pretty close - been here 3 times and tried 3 different things -

first time - bbq mixed plate - not bad. chicken and beef was acceptable but the short rib was all fat. mac salad was ok and the take out container is high quality...

second time - loco moco - not good. the egg was good (hard to screw up an egg tho), but the hamburger was just weird - in terms of consistency. the gravy was lite but had flavor...

third time - bento box - best value so far - the chicken and beef are passable and you get a piece of ham and a deep fried piece of mahi mahi (would be nice if there was a broiled option)....
author: Joe M.

description: Cheap and fast. The food in hot food line seems fresh. Great service. Good value for FiDi.
author: L S.

description:
So here's the trick with this place: Don't get suckered by the cashier into going through the chinese food line!  

My coworkers and I walked into this place today on a whim, with the intention of getting Hawaiian bbq.  We were motioned over to the area that looks like every other quick chinese-lunch place in town, and it wasn't until after I had already answered "fried rice" to the usual "rice or noodles" question that I realized that there wasn't a single hawaiian bbq option in the tubs of food in front of me.  Two other people I was with fell for the same ploy.  Only the last guy realized that he had to order directly from the cashier if he wanted something off the menu.

For what it's worth, I'm told the fried shrimp he got wasn't very good.  Whatever I got (two items, both with chicken in them) was terrible.  I probably won't be back, unless I decide I have to try the hawaiian options.
author: Jason M.

description:
Owner - super friendly/nice (if you get to know him he'll give you free stuff)

Food- fresh and delicious (brown rice available, yay!)

Cost- a little more than an average chinese place

Variety - GREAT! Try the Hawaiian bento box.. 

Better to phone in your order and then pick it up later instead of waiting there...
author: Catalina C.

description:
Wow, I'm amazed. I looked this place up expecting it to have close to five stars and was shocked to see only three. Then I read the 1-star reviews and realized why. People! You do not come here for their sweet and sour pork or any of that Panda Express garbage, this place has incredibly AUTHENTIC Chinese food available!  Now, I do have to put some of the blame on them as some of the best stuff is not on the menu so you kind of have to know what you want or you're stuck with the yucky Americanized crap that no self-respecting Chinese person would touch with a ten-foot pole.  It seems like a lot of people here are under the impression that all you can get here is the heat-lamp stuff?? So not true, this place is all about their made-to-order dishes.

My whole office is hooked on this place ever since we discovered the chicken crispy noodles (which are not on the menu), you have to make sure to order it with light sauce or sometimes they are too soggy, but without a doubt these are some of the best Hong Kong style noodles I have ever had. Their wor wonton soup is also top notch and I always enjoy their black bean chicken.  My friend who introduced me to this place lived in HK his whole childhood and assures me that this place has the best Singaporean noodles he has ever had.  Their salt and pepper calamari is yummy too but we can't have it in the office because of the smell!  Please don't judge this place on the pre-made food because they clearly just make that stuff to try to appeal to people who aren't sure how or what to order.  Be adventurous!  Try something on their extensive menu, or if there's a dish you you've tried somewhere else before ask them if they make it because they just well might.

The trick to getting around the long wait is to order ahead of time, I've never gone there without calling in an order first and they actually recognize our office number now so they know exactly how pretty much everyone in the office likes their orders. 

Oh, their breakfast is cheap, large portions and they don't use fake eggs.  Can't speak for their Hawaiian bbq because I've never personally tried it but some people in my office seem to like it.
author: wingless g.

description: the taste i am ok with them...not the owner that his way does to the consumer...when the store just open for the price ok. the food portion good......later on rise the price, i understand , but it cut portion of the food ....i could feel that ...now even worse. he is using the containter is shorter then before, that mean the food portion get cut again ....i wont be back again ......
author: Jianwei J.

description: OK... i came back a few times because my co workers love this place. After that one incident I had, this place really grew on me. The workers know me and are very sweet. I actually really like their food now. I come here at least twice a month. I've tried almost everything including breakfast and it's very good for the price.
author: Nicole H.

description:
FOOD POISONING.  A co-worker mentioned to me that he got food poisoning there shortly after they opened.  I'd already been eating lunch there, so I kept on going... but a few weeks ago, after having two chicken dishes from here, I got the worst food poisoning I'd ever had in my life.  The only food I had that day was Jamba Juice for breakfast and then lunch here...  and what made me sick was not a frozen Strawberry Whirl from Jamba Juice.  Sweats, chills, lightheadedness, diarrhea, vomiting.  I couldn't eat anything for 2 days, and it was 4 days before I was back to normal.  

I feel kind of bad writing this since the staff there all seem so darned nice... but y'all should know the risks.
author: Steve R.

description: My coworkers like this place.  I've had their wonton noodle soup, which I thought was oily.  I then tried their sweet and sour soup, which tasted like a powder mix.  Most people get the combination plates (which reminded me of panda express).  But I think the prices are reasonable, and it's worth a try if you're looking for a new place, but I wouldn't say I'm a regular.
author: Annie R.

description:
I have been going here since they opened and am totally happy.  the Hawaiian BBQ is average, but the made to order Chinese food rocks.  They will even make you stuff off the menu, just ask! 

I am happy that they are just across the street from my building so it is totally convenient and they are open later so that if you are totally starving at like 3 you can get made to order hot food! 

The staff is friendly is nice.  Love it!
author: Cindy F.

description: We eat here frequently for lunch.  The food is solid and the service is friendly.  Can't go wrong for the price here.
author: Allen A.
