description: Today is my veggie day, my coworker referred me to this place for their veggie dishes. When I looked at their to go menu, there wasn't anything that sparkled my eyes. But with limited time to decide, I went with her referral. I ordered stir fried string bean over rice. The dish came out to the a little spicy, it was mixed with carrots and some preserved pickle veggie. The taste was not bad. Why 3 stars? Because of the rice. The rice tasted a little funny..somewhat different from white rice I normally get from a chinse restaurant. It tasted like those vietnamese broken rice. There's a very funny texture to it..totally unexpectable.
author: Bon T.

description: First and foremost, the name of this place is weird. I get the Chinese Cuisine but not sure where the Hawaiian BBQ comes in to play. Nonetheless, I really like this place. It is exactly what you expect from a fast food Chinese food place. The people barely speak English and they move you through quickly but that is sort of what I am going for. LOVE the egg rolls and sesame chicken.
author: Brianna R.

description: I've just discovered a new lunch spot!  I had a hackerin' for some Hawaiian food and I had passed 77 Chinese Cuisine and Hawaiian BBQ on my way home one day.  It's a little far from my building, but totally worth the walk.  They've got a take-out counter and you could get cooked-to-order food too.   It's cheap too.
author: Melanie B.

description:
Grabbed some pork dumplings around 4PM for a snack.  It took ten minutes for them to steam the dumplings.  So I went for a stroll and went back in eager anticipation.  Heck - it must be fresh right since I had to wait.

Wrong! I can't taste anything but salt, salt, and more salt.  I bet they used three tablespoons of salt for those four dumplings.  

Four lousy dumplings for $3.25 plus tax.   These were the worst dim sum I've ever had!  Now, I have to get back to the water cooler & chug water.
author: D C.

description: I've eaten here only several hundred times over the last few years. Good Cantonese food - order off the menu rather than from the buffet bar. That way the food will be cooked fresh, and you can get the best dishes (as opposed to the Americanized Chinese food that they serve from the bar). Dishes to try: Wor Won Ton Soup, Pork & Preserved Egg Porridge, Salt and Pepper Spareribs, Broccoli Beef, Sweet and Sour Pork, Fried Chicken Wings. An underrated lunch place, to be sure.
author: W. T.

description: I decided to try this place for shits and giggles after walking by a number of times.  I ordered the mocco locco which made for a heavy lunch.  It was tasty, but like I said heavy.  The service to take the order was quick, but the wait to get the food was long.  When I was done I had to shit and then I giggled.
author: T-Bone L.

description: For lunch, it definitely satisfies your craving if you want your basic wonton noodle soup.   I usually get the buffet and I enjoy the fresh stir fry of ho fun (wide) noodles with some buk choy and tofu.  I haven't tried all their selections because you have to be in the mood for it.  They definitely pile the food in your nice to go containers and the ladies behind the counter are eager to help.  I enjoyed their Hawaiian BBQ too but I'll stick to their chinese food.  I haven't tried their congee or dim sim yet.
author: pengrin ..

description: I had zero expectation for this place except for the fact I don't want to go to Focaccia 3 days in a roll and was craving some greasy spoon Chinese food (minus the meat). Surprisingly enough, there were a few vegetarian dishes that can be made to order. I opted for the Kung Pao Tofu (and asked for it to be extra spicy). The portion was generous and very flavorful (tangy and not really spicy but still good). At a price tag of $6.50 (tax inclusive), it was a decent (but probably not the healthiest) weekday lunch option in the middle of financial district. Will be back to try rest of their vegetarian repertoire.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Had lunch there today.  Large portions, decent quality, for a very reasonable price (particularly for downtown financial district).  I went there for the Hawaiian BBQ, but didn't actually see any Chicken Katsu and mac salad behind the glass, so I ended up ordering a couple Chinese dishes -- chicken curry and chicken with green beans.  Their paper menus say they have Hawaiian-style plate lunches (which I miss from my days living on Oahu), but I decided not to ask, as I figured the stuff out front was probably freshest.  I would definitely go back, when looking for a cheap, big, hot lunch.
author: Fred E.

description:
i've gotten the same dish several times. 

this place has by far the best War Won Ton Noodle soup in the city; this coming from someone that always orders this soup every time i eat chinese food. the combination of ingredients taste fresh and the noodles and wonton casings don't taste doughy or slimy. 

my coworkers go here a lot and come highly recommended. staff is pretty friendly as well.
author: amos u.

description: Very good food! I work downtown SF and I have yet to get tired of this restaurant. Their food is fresh and plates are very well proportioned. I highly recommend The Salt and Pepper Spare Ribs. That is definitely on my plate every time I go. The people are nice and waiting time is not too bad if you go around 11:30AM.
author: Cristian G.

description: I've never been to the actual store but we order in from our office every week. The name says Hawaiin but what they really excel in is authentic chinese greasiness. Totally satifies the hunger! I usually order their salt and pepper spareribs over rice but they also have a fine selection of spicy tofu and seafood rice combinations. Definitely one of the best chinese places in the fidi.
author: Patrick M.

description:
As far as lunch places go in the FiDi, this place isn't half bad.  They definitely have a wide selection from the typical chinese rice plate lunches to a bento lunch (with fish, steak, chicken, and ham) and some Hawaiian selections (loco moco and other bbq items).  They also had a hand written menu that includes some breakfast items like french toast, pancakes, and omlettes.  Honestly, this place reminds me of the closed down restaurant "Banana's" on Pine St with it's wide selection (that place had thai rice plates, burgers, and breakfast food, too). 

I ordered the Loco Moco and it was pretty well done.  The gravy wasn't too salty, the eggs were fried just right (slightly runny), and the 2 hamburger patties were not dry at all.  I actually enjoyed the side of macaroni salad which wasn't drowned in mayo like typical Hawaiian fare (i.e. L&L).  Buddy of mine got the Bento and thought it was on the salty side though.  

The place is new and clean with very pleasant service (atypical of chinese restaurants).  I give it 3 stars and will be back to try the french toast some day....
author: David C.

description: Delicious won ton soup! It's light, non-greasy, the wonton filling is a nice shrimp and pork mix. I can't vouch for the rest of the stuff there, but wonton soup is on hit.
author: Danielle J.

description:
I've been going to this place since it opened and watched it go through growing pains.  The owner is one of the nicest guys I know - we've changed office locations (to one much further away) and he still delivers to us every week, rain or shine.  

Ordering the panda express-type menu items will give you just that - generic greasy "Chinese" food.  There are off menu items, like at most lrestaurants in Chinatown, and there are some solid regular items (black bean fish, string bean chicken, curry chicken, salt/pepper/garlic porkchops and chicken wings to name several) are always favorites with the coworkers, and their jook and wor wonton soups are excellent hangover cures.  I'm told they make their own (excellent) hot sauce as well.  

There are definite misses as well - we've been customizing our weekly orders and they don't always get each item right - but generally speaking the quality of the operation outweighs this.  

Legit Chinese food in FiDi, plus a side of bbq.  I'm still trying to convince him to add spam musubi.
author: Sai-Kit C.

description: One of the best choice for authentic Chinese food in the FiDi.  Order from the menu.  The buffet counter selection does not represent the wide range of delicious options they offer.  Everyone works there is super nice.
author: Mary S.

description: Okay, went there for lunch. Had a craving for Chinese with the option for Hawaiian. When I arrived at 11:50 am I successfully beat the lunch hour rush and decided on brown rice with eggplant/tofu and Mongolian Chicken. I sprung for the two-item plate  which, with a small fountain drink, came to around $8-ish. It was okay. The eggplant dish was kinda sweet which was a surprise to me. The Mongolian Chicken was tasty. The brown rice was healthy. Next time I'll probably order something Hawaiian and close my eyes and pretend I'm in Waikiki instead of the good old FiDi.
author: Van D.

description: Bland, tepid food at spicy, hot prices.   I got the Mongolian chicken, and the two red chilis I found in my dish had obviously fallen off a dried flower arrangement - they did nothing but look pretty.  The chow mein noodles were al dente.  Leftovers perhaps?  New Asia Cuisine in the Crocker Galleria has much better food for the same price.
author: Teri G.

description: Was looking for a halfway decent chinese takeout place, similar to Panda Express - so the bar wasn't very high. But food isn't particularly tasty (nor spicy either), its edible and non-greasy but not worth going for - esp. with the amount of choices nearby.
author: Alok K.

description: i agree! So good, it's going to be our new mainstay. Oh, but if you're like me and you hate mayo, be sure to ask them not to give you a scoop of macaroni salad.
author: Amy K.

description: One of the few, if not the only, Hawaiian options in the Financial District.  A quick lunch--with sizable portions that are reasonably priced--and an always-friendly staff to boot.
author: Andrea U.

description: Had a super late lunch here yesterday and I'm still thinking about it today. I got the tofu and chicken and I couldn't believe how good it was. Fried to golden perfection and melt in your mouth goodness in the middle. The staff is also very friendly.
author: Sophia C.

description: By FiDi lunch standards (the lowest common denominator), this is a solid spot.  Some of the one-star reviews need to check their expectations; this ain't Clement Street.  You can pick one to three already prepared items, or have what you want made to order.  I prefer the latter, especially the Mongolian Chicken.  The price is right and the service awesome.  The owner is super friendly and always good for an enthusiatic greeting.
author: Leon R.

description: Generous slabs of sub-par meats.  Not exactly a medley of complex flavors on the palette.  The chicken tasted like beef, the beef tasted like chicken, and the broccoli hiding under both tasted like, well, both.  The rice was dry, and the mac salad was horrendous. Sugar and mayonnaise mixed with chewy, al dente macaroni. Yum.  My friend complained about his mahimahi, with good reason.  Over battered frozen fish.  Most of it was left on the plate.
author: Ben N.

description: This place is gross. I had the BBQ Chicken plate. It is not authentic Hawaiian at all. The chicken just had a ton of soy sauce on it and reaked of cheap Teriyaki dressing. The mac salad I think you can buy in bulk at CostCo.It's just really bad food. I can't believe that suckers buy this crap. Never again Hawaiian BBQ. I wont be fooled twice.
author: brandon m.

description: Had the sesame chicken off the steam table with chow mein today.  I thought they were pretty generous for once with the portions.  Once I brought this back to work though I found out the sesame chicken was absent of any sesame.  There was a more than ample portion but what's the point of a lackluster dish.
author: Robert C.

description: I have tried their takeout lunch several times and I give it 4 stars.  For Chinese takeout, the food tastes pretty good.  Their chicken with tofu or fried rice with seafood are yummy.  The steam table offers quite a bit of varieties, well balance of choices of veggies and meat.  The workers there are very nice and cheerful.  These days, finding a cheap but good place in Financial district is almost impossible.  $7 per plate is a bit expensive to me but worths to have once every 2 weeks, especially when I am hungry on that day.
author: Roserrele W.

description: Eh, it's alright.  I stopped by today craving some Hawaiian BBQ, and while it wasn't bad, it wasn't very good either.  I got the mixed BBQ plate which comes with chicken teriyaki, short ribs, and steak teriyaki.  The quality of the chicken wasn't that great but the ribs were pretty good and the steak was ok.  I don't think I'll be rushing back anytime soon but wouldn't be too surprised if I try it again, although next time I think I'll opt for the chinese food which is similar to a Panda Express setup.  From the looks other people's orders, it seems like you get a ton of food for between $5.50-7.50 depending on if you want 1, 2, or 3 items.
author: Niall H.

description:
I've only ordered from the kitchen and never from the steam table line. If it's not a complete madhouse I only have to wait maybe 5 minutes. You could call ahead too.

The Chinese food can be hit or miss but none of it has been bad. The string bean chicken is bland but has a ton of veggies. Mongolian beef isn't nuclear but serviceable. You can always ask for stuff to be made spicy, the staff is super friendly. Chicken with black bean sauce is good, as is the chow mein. The fried rice is great. I haven't tried the Hawaiian BBQ yet because I was just so glad to find decent Chinese food.

Servings are definitely enough to have leftovers if you're not really hungry which is nice in the land of the $9 sandwich.
author: James D.

description: This is a pretty good Chinese take out place with steam tables. I give them 3 stars, +1 because they have my favorite Chinese dish - Peking Spare Ribs. Don't get the fried rice, it is kinda dry.
author: Joon L.

description: Holy crap, delicious. I was sitting at work, slightly hung over from a Halloween party last night, and I decided I needed some greasy Chinese food. I looked for the nearest place on Yelp and found this, and now I am happily munching on some fried rice, sweet & sour pork, and green bean chicken. The green beans are wonderfully crispy and everything is totally soaking in grease, it's great. It all comes in a giant plastic container with "Microwave Safe" etched on top, perfect for storing in the fridge so I can eat more later (I could never finish all of this in one sitting!). $7 for enough food to last me all day!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: I've been slacking on writing a review, but the time has finally arrived.  I love this place, I've been a regular here and their service is great.  Always smiling and offering free drinks and soups.  They have a good variety of Chinese dishes and now offering dim sum as well.  You can get the buffet style lunch or order a dish from the menu.  It can be a bit frustrating at times when you arrive after 12pm because the line just builts up and there is literally no room in this place.  If you are looking for a decent place to grab good Chinese food with reasonable price in the area, this is it.
author: Jeff L.

description: I wish I could give this place NO STARS.  This is the worse Chinese food.  Having been a few times trying to convince myself its good, I have decided its not.  I ordered the Kung Pao Chicken today 6/12/08 it was disgusting and it was almost $7.00!  Three pieces of chicken, the rest consisted horrible veggies that probably have been sitting around all day.  If you want real Chinese food go to Henry Hunan's! They are the best! I will no longer frequent this dump again!
author: Unemployed A.

description: I didn't eat their Chinese, I went specifically to test out their Hawaiian bbq chicken, macaroni and rice.  I've had L&L (really good).  77's was...edible but not much else to say about it.  The macaroni salad was just ok, nothing outstanding.  The rice was rice.  The chicken would have been better if they'd grilled it rather than fried it (you can smell and taste the oil).  I ordered take out because I had to get back to work and when I opened the container at my desk, I found there was NO sauce at all on the chicken (which would have been just fine except for the greasy taste).  I have to give 77 one star because it is open from 6am to 6pm on weekdays and open on Sat too so I may be coming back here a lot (not many cheap eateries open in the FiDi on the weekends), and another star because the staff was so genial and friendly.  I'll have to come back to try their Chinese (probably won't do the Hawaiian bbq again).
author: Kai T.

description: Im a regular here and this place, although pricey, is a good place to eat and for the finacial district. Its a deal, cheaper than Lee's Deli. here i never spend more than 7 dollars for lunch and for me thats a bargen since everywhere else its like 8 to 10 dollars. go 77
author: Alejandro B.

description: What are people talking about here? This place was not good. Lukewarm noodles with dry, rubbery chicken, and another blah chicken dish. I only had the Chinese food. I may go back to try the Hawiian food, but I'll have to be pretty desperate.
author: Tina Z.
